internalName.en-US: Start Page - About this service - content

content.value: This is a self-assessment service to determine how your school plans for and uses digital technology for teaching, learning and administration.
Your answers will generate recommendations and actions. These can help your school to use digital technology to support cost savings, workload reduction and improved outcomes.

The questions will be tailored to your school’s circumstances so the number and type of questions you’ll be asked will vary.
Before you start each section, you’ll see specific information to help you answer the questions.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - interstitial page - Preparing for broadband connection topic - content

content.value: Fast, reliable broadband can support teaching and learning. Your contract should state what type of broadband you have. This could be:
copper, also described as fibre to the cabinet (FTTC) or asymmetric digital subscriber line (ADSL)
full fibre, also described as fibre to the premises (FTTP) or leased line
other, this could be 5G, satellite or another connection
This topic includes a maximum of 4 multiple choice questions about your broadband connection. Depending on your responses, you might not need to answer all the questions.

your school's broadband type
the bandwidth capacity, for example, 1Gbps upload and download speed
if fibre broadband is available in your school's area, use the
Ofcom broadband checker
or ask your broadband provider
Some schools prefer to have a meeting with all relevant people so they can answer the questions together. Alternatively, an individual team member can complete the topic.
There is no time limit. You can leave and return to the service at any time as your answers automatically save as you go along.

internalName.en-US: Backup broadband - interstitial Page - Preparing for backup broadband topic - content

content.value:
Back-up broadband is an additional broadband connection that your school can use if your primary broadband fails for any reason. It should keep your school’s core operations running until your primary broadband is fixed.  

Back-up broadband does not ‘back-up’ data or files. 

This topic includes a maximum of 6 multiple choice questions about your back-up broadband. Depending on your responses, you might not need to answer all the questions.

internalName.en-US: Network cabling - interstitial page - Preparing for the network cabling topic - content

content.value: Network cabling refers to the cables that run from your network switches to different parts of your school. They connect devices or wifi access points to your school’s external broadband connection.
Network cabling may be inside walls, protected by cable trunking or attached to walls or ceilings. Cabling that runs between school buildings is usually underground or suspended at height.
This topic includes a maximum of 3 multiple choice questions about network switches. Depending on your responses, you might not need to answer all the questions.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - low recs - What to consider - content

content.value: Full fibre broadband, also described as fibre to the premises (FTTP) or leased line, is the recommended standard for schools.
Installing or upgrading broadband can involve structural work to both your premises and nearby roads. You'll need to fund and plan for this to avoid disruption during term time.

Many things can affect broadband speed and reliability. As well as upgrading your broadband connection, check that the rest of your network meets digital and technology standards in schools and colleges. This includes:
network cabling
network switches
wireless network
If you share a fibre connection with another school, this can also make your broadband slow and unreliable at peak times.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - low recs - Why recommendation is important - content

content.value: Copper broadband services, including asymmetric digital subscriber line (ADSL) and fibre to the cabinet (FTTC), will be switched off at the end of December 2025.
After this date, copper broadband will no longer work.
The switch-off will happen in phases and may occur sooner in some areas.

internalName.en-US: Broadband Connection - low recs - What it can help you achieve - content

content.value: Faster, more reliable broadband can help your school to:
use technology to support pupils better
communicate quickly and easily with teachers, pupils and other stakeholders
save time with faster connection speeds
allow flexible working, where relevant
move to the cloud, which can save money, improve security and increase sustainability
meet or exceed
broadband internet standards for schools and colleges

text.en-US: How to purchase broadband

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - low recs - Consider level broadband needed - content

content.value: Bandwidth download and upload speeds should follow
broadband internet standards for schools and colleges
. Minimum standards are:
1Gbps download and upload speed for secondary schools
100Mbps download speed and 30Mbps upload speed for primary schools
Remember to consider your school’s future needs. Larger schools and those using or planning to use more cloud-based applications for teaching, learning or other operations, might need more bandwidth.

To help work this out, check with your broadband provider to find out how often you reach peak usage. Reaching peak usage can cause your internet to slow down, which can affect teaching and learning. If this is more than 80% of the time, consider talking to your provider about increasing your capacity.

Some providers include extra ‘bundle’ services such as filtering and monitoring, domain name hosting, email and more. Consider these and other services you might need and the savings you might make. Bundles can be better value. Make sure you are comparing like-for-like quotes so that you can choose the best value option.
Make sure that your new contract includes all the bundled services you need, if you move to a different broadband provider. If not, you might need to buy extra services from other providers.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - low recs - How to purchase - content

content.value: Changing your school broadband could involve extra costs. This should be planned for and included in your school improvement plan.
Put together a specification for broadband connection that meets your school’s needs. The
Get help buying for schools service

can help. Consider potential increases in pupil numbers or one device per pupil projects. Plans for installations that use lots of data, such as CCTV, a media suite or Wi-Fi 6, will also affect your broadband needs.
When comparing quotes and choosing a provider, make sure you consider:
the level of service on offer and if it includes the same bundled services and service agreements
if it includes additional services that meet
filtering and monitoring standards for schools and colleges
You should choose a contract that:
is 3 years or fewer in length as technology changes quickly
if relevant, allows you to upgrade to full fibre broadband when it becomes available in your area
The
telecoms and broadband matching frameworks service
can help you find preferred providers.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - Shared broadband - header H3

text.en-US: Shared broadband

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - low recs - Plan changes to broadband - content

content.value: Copper broadband, also described as ADSL and FTTC, is being phased out. This is a rolling programme, with the final switch-off planned for the end of December 2025.
If your school is affected, it’s important that you plan now to make sure you continue to have a reliable, supported broadband connection.
To do this:
Check with your provider when copper broadband will be phased out in your area.
Check with your provider, or ask a different provider, to find out if full fibre broadband is available in your area.
If full fibre broadband is not available, find out what your options are, this could be satellite, 5G or another connection.
Understand the costs and work involved, including installation, set up and monthly contract.
Cost any extra services you may need, such as filtering and monitoring, email, domain name hosting.
Include the necessary funding in your school improvement plan (SIP).

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - Low recs - Review regularly - content

content.value: Keep your broadband contract information updated on your contracts register.

To make sure your broadband continues to meet your school’s needs, review your contract at least once a year, even if your contract period is longer. This means that if changes need to be made that involve funding, you can put plans in place.
Always review your contract at least 6 months before it ends. If you need to make changes or switch providers, there may be a lengthy notice period.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - low recs - Plan changes to broadband - header

text.en-US: Plan changes to your broadband connection

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - Low recs - Prepare to switch - content

content.value: Make sure you know how much notice you must give your current provider. This could be more than 6 months before your contract ends.
When the notice period opens, follow your provider’s instructions to let them know you will be changing or ending your contract.
On the day your broadband switchover takes place make sure your IT support is available, preferably on site, to help with network setting changes. Ask your IT support to check the settings meet
filtering and monitoring standards for schools and colleges

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - How to purchase broadband - content

content.value: Changing your school broadband could involve extra cost. This should be planned for and included in your school improvement plan.
Put together a specification for broadband connection that meets your school’s needs. The
Get help buying for schools service

can help. Consider potential increases in pupil numbers or one device per pupil projects. Plans for installations that use lots of data, such as CCTV, a media suite or Wi-Fi 6, will also affect your broadband needs.
When comparing quotes and choosing a provider, make sure you consider:
the level of service on offer and if it includes the same bundled services and service agreements

Try to choose a contract that:

allows you to upgrade your bandwidth if your needs change

internalName.en-US: Vision and roles - mid recs - What to consider before start - content

content.value: Always think about how technology can help your school to meet its educational needs.
Not all schools use the same terminology. For example, you may call your technology strategy a digital strategy, an innovation strategy or something else.

internalName.en-US: Visions and roles - low recs - Appoint IT link gov - content

content.value: Your board of governors should include at least one governor, usually called an IT link governor, who is responsible for technology. This person may have an interest in IT and should have skills to monitor and challenge decisions about technology.
They should not, however, lead the technology strategy.
Your IT link governor should have clearly defined and documented responsibilities. They're also responsible for approving your technology strategy, making sure it:
is in line with your technology vision
supports educational needs
is properly resourced and funded
complies with legislation
helps to keep staff, pupils and visitors safe and secure
includes plans for disaster recovery and business continuity
considers and plans for future needs
is discussed at governing body meetings
is reviewed and updated at least once a year

internalName.en-US: Vision and roles - low recs - Develop tech strat for ed needs - content

content.value: Your

SLT member responsible for technology should work with your IT support, subject leads and other school professionals. Together they should identify your school’s educational and operational needs. Using this information, your SLT member responsible for technology should create a technology strategy, including plans and funding needed:
to maintain and upgrade the network
to upgrade or buy equipment and software that supports teaching and learning
for ongoing training and continuous professional development
for ongoing support and maintenance
for major technology investment projects
It should also include plans for:
complying with data protection, safeguarding and other legislation
disaster recovery and business continuity plans
understanding and identifying training needs
refreshing, reusing or replacing equipment in the future
Your technology strategy should be shared and agreed with the wider SLT and signed off by your IT link governor.

internalName.en-US: Vision and roles - low recs - Develop tech strat for ed needs - header

text.en-US: Develop a technology strategy that meets educational needs

internalName.en-US: Vision and roles - low recs - Add tech to SIP - content

content.value: Your technology plan should be included in your SIP.
Include technology as an agenda point at your SLT and governing body meetings.
This helps to make sure that technology continues to support educational needs.
It also improves understanding and engagement and keeps your wider leadership team up  to date with progress.
Review your technology strategy at least once a year, in line with your SIP.

internalName.en-US: Network cabling - low recs - What to consider before start - content

content.value: Replacing old network cabling can be expensive and disruptive. Only consider replacing network cabling:
that is faulty
that is out of warranty and causing your network to slow down or fail
when planning a refurbishment
Installing a mix of new cabling and wifi access points can reduce overall network cabling. This can give more flexibility in the future as every device does not need to be linked to a network point.
Any cabling connected to your wifi access points must be at least category 6A.

internalName.en-US: Network cabling - recs no work [low] - Why important - content

content.value: Network cabling can affect the speed, reliability and quality of your internet.
Older types of network cabling may create a bottleneck for applications or installations that use a lot of data, such as CCTV, media suites or Wi-Fi 6.

internalName.en-US: Network cabling - recs no work [low] - Find out type - content

content.value: If the cabling is visible, you can see the type of cabling printed on the sheath.
Look for the word CAT followed by numbers and letters. CAT 6A cabling or above meets the
network cabling standards for schools and colleges
. CAT 6, CAT 5E, CAT 5 or lower do not meet the standard.
There may be more than one type of cabling in your school if your building has been refurbished or extended.

Due to the risk of asbestos and the possibility of damaging the cables, do not penetrate walls to check the cable type. If the wording is unclear or cables are hidden from view, either check with your provider or arrange for a professional to test the cabling.

internalName.en-US: Network cabling - recs no work [low] - Consider cabling if doing future work - content

content.value: In the future, return to the
network cabling topic
, update your answers and follow the new recommendations if your school decides to:
refurbish part or all of your school buildings
build or extend school buildings
install a media suite
give one device per pupil, for example, tablets
move to the cloud
install new wifi infrastructure, for example, Wi-Fi 6
install other applications or devices that use a lot of data, for example, CCTV

internalName.en-US: Network cabling - recs no work [low] - Document type - content

content.value: Record the type, location and installation date (or approximate year) of your network cabling on your school’s asset register. This is a list of your school’s physical assets, including type of asset, supplier, installation date, warranty and location. Make sure this document is available to everyone who makes decisions about technology in your school.
When you know what type of cabling you have, if you can, work out if it meets
network cabling standards for schools and colleges
. Add this extra information to your asset register. Keep in mind:
cabling installed before 2009 will not meet the standards
cabling installed after 2009 may meet the standards, but this will need to be confirmed
for safety, and to avoid a fire risk, assume that any unknown cabling does not meet the standards
Make sure that the senior leadership team and other decision makers are aware of the school’s cabling type or types.

internalName.en-US: Network cabling - recs plan work [med + high] - Actions to take - content

content.value: Follow these actions if your network cabling needs replacing. This could be because your cabling is causing problems with your IT network or your school is investing in:
a refurbishment
building work
technology that uses a lot of data, for example, CCTV, a media suite or Wi-Fi 6
If your school is already taking any of these actions, move to the next action.

internalName.en-US: Network cabling - recs plan work [med + high] - What help to achieve - content

content.value: Installing network cabling that meets digital and technology standards for schools and colleges, when refurbishing or extending your building can:
save money in the long term
help to meet your school’s technology needs
provide capacity for future technological growth
allow investment in technology to enhance teaching and improve student outcomes
provide the foundation for moving to the cloud

text.en-US: Find out what type of cabling is installed in your school

internalName.en-US: Network cabling - recs plan work [med + high] - Consider cabling needs build - content

content.value: Make sure you include network cabling in any plans for capital building work. This can include a full or part refurbishment, a new building or an extension.
Talk to your IT support about your network cabling needs. These can depend on:
the type of devices currently used in your school
plans to introduce cloud solutions
plans for one device per pupil
plans to install applications that use a lot of data, for example, CCTV, a media suite or Wi-Fi 6

Ask your supplier or contractor if it’s possible to reduce the amount of cabling needed by installing wifi access points. This could give your school more flexibility in the future as every device does not need to be linked to a network point.

internalName.en-US: Network cabling - recs plan work [med + high] - Wifi replace cable - content

content.value: Installing wifi access points means that you do not need to install cabling to every device, for example, laptops and desktop computers. This can give your school more flexibility in how you use technology.
This might not be suitable for all schools. Check with your IT support and complete the wifi infrastructure questions in the
wireless networking topic
to see if your school could benefit.
Wifi is only as good as the cabling connecting it to the network switches. Make sure cabling connecting wifi access points to switches is at least CAT 6A.

content.value: If your network cabling does not meet network cabling standards for schools and colleges, it might not be able to support new technology. Check with your IT provider, whether or not you need new cabling, if your school is planning to:
give one device per pupil, for example, tablets
move to the cloud
install new wifi infrastructure, for example, Wi-Fi 6
install other applications or devices that use a lot of data, for example, CCTV
Make sure new network cabling meets
network cabling standards for school and colleges
The
Get help buying for schools service
can help you put together a specification.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - interstitial page - How your school can benefit - content

content.value:
We’ll use your answers to give you a better understanding of what your school is doing well, along with recommendations to help you do some things even better.  

This could include working out if your school needs to upgrade its broadband, which could involve investment. The recommendations will help you to understand how to plan for this.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - Question 1 - Answer - 1 to 2 years

text.en-US: Every 1 to 2 years

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - low recs - Shared broadband - content

content.value: If you share your broadband with a nearby school, consider installing your own broadband.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - low recs - Join central contract - content

content.value: Check if there's a centralised or trust-wide contract your school can join. There might be a better deal you can benefit from. Your school business manager and, if relevant, your local authority or multi-academy trust (MAT) should be able to help.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - low recs - Join central contract - header

text.en-US: Find out if your school can join a centralised contract

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - low recs - Shared broadband - header

text.en-US: Shared broadband

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - What to consider before start - content

content.value: Full fibre broadband, also described as fibre to the premises (FTTP) or leased line, is the recommended standard for schools.
Installing or upgrading broadband can involve work both to your premises and nearby roads. You need to fund and plan this to avoid disruption during term time.

Many things can affect broadband speed and reliability. As well as upgrading your broadband connection, check that the rest of your network meets digital and technology standards for schools and colleges, including:
network cabling
network switches
wireless network
If you share a fibre connection with another school, this can also make your broadband slow and unreliable at peak times.
Having broadband that meets your needs now and for the next few years will make sure your connection continues to meet your school’s educational needs.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - Plan to install or upgrade - title

text.en-US: Have a plan to upgrade or install full fibre broadband

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - What rec can help achieve - content

content.value: Faster, more reliable broadband can help your school to:
use technology to support pupils better
communicate quickly and easily with teachers, pupils and other stakeholders
save time with faster connection speeds
allow flexible working where relevant
move to the cloud, which can save money, improve security and increase sustainability
meet or exceed
broadband internet standards for schools and colleges

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - Doc info about contract - header

text.en-US: Document information about your broadband contract

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - Find what types available - content

content.value: Use the
Ofcom broadband checker
to find out if full fibre broadband is available in your area. If not, use the
Openreach tool
to find out if full fibre broadband is coming to your area soon.

If full fibre broadband is unavailable for your school, check with your broadband provider that you are using the best alternative. Satellite, 5G or, in some areas of the country, wireless broadband could be available. To choose the best option for your school, discuss the pros and cons of these alternative broadband connections with your provider and IT support.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - Consider level needed - header

text.en-US: Consider the level of broadband and bandwidth your school needs

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - Consider level needed - content

content.value: Bandwidth download and upload speeds should follow
broadband internet standards for schools and colleges
. Minimum standards are:
1Gbps download and upload speed for secondary schools
100Mbps download speed and 30Mbps upload speed for primary schools

Larger schools and those using, or planning to use, more cloud-based applications for teaching, learning or other operations might need more bandwidth. If you need more capacity, ask your provider about upgrade options.

To help work this out, check with your broadband provider to find out how often you reach peak usage. Reaching peak usage can cause your internet to slow, which can affect teaching and learning. If this is more than 80% of the time, consider talking to your provider about increasing your capacity.

Some providers include extra ‘bundle’ services such as filtering and monitoring, domain name hosting, email and more. Consider these and other services you might need and the savings you might make. Bundles can save you money. Make sure you are comparing like-for-like quotes so that you can get better value for money.
Make sure that your new contract includes all the bundled services you need, if you move to a different broadband provider. If not, you might need to buy extra services from other providers.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - Find what types available - header

text.en-US: Find out what broadband types are available for your school

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - Doc info about contract - content

content.value: Check your broadband contract or contact your provider to find out:
the type of broadband your school uses, for example, 5G, FTTP or other type
what, if any, bundled services you pay for, including email, domain name hosting, filtering and monitoring
your broadband renewal date and notice period, which could be 6 months or more
if you can increase your bandwidth capacity, in case your needs change before renewal
Your school business professional, or whoever is in charge of buying in your school, should have access to the broadband connection contract.

Record this information on your contracts register. This is a list of your school’s contracts, including type of contract, provider, and start, end and review dates. Make sure this document is available to everyone who makes decisions about technology in your school.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - Shared broadband - content

content.value: If you share your broadband with a nearby school, consider installing your own broadband.

content.value: Check if there's a centralised or trust-wide contract your school can join. There might be a better deal you can benefit from. Your school business manager and, if relevant, your local authority or multi-academy trust (MAT) should be able to help.

text.en-US: Continue to review your broadband contract

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - high recs - Review 1 x year - header

text.en-US: Review your broadband contract at least once a year

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - high recs - Things to consider - content

content.value: Many things can affect broadband speed and reliability. If your school broadband is slow or unreliable, check that the rest of your network meets digital and technology standards for schools and colleges. This includes:
network cabling
network switches
wireless network

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - high recs - Actions to take - content

content.value: From your answers your school is meeting, and possibly exceeding, the
broadband internet standards for schools and colleges

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - high recs - Things to consider - header

text.en-US: Things to consider

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - How to prepare for switch - content

content.value: Make sure you know how much notice you must give your current provider. This could be more than 6 months before your contract ends.
When the notice period opens, follow your provider’s instructions to let them know you will be changing or ending your contract.
On the day your broadband switchover takes place make sure your IT support is available, preferably on site, to help with network setting changes. Ask your IT support to check the settings meet
filtering and monitoring standards for schools and colleges

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - Review 1 x year - header

text.en-US: Review your broadband contract at least once a year

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - med recs - Review 1 x year - content

content.value: Keep your broadband contract information updated on your contracts register.

To make sure your broadband continues to meet your school’s needs, review your contract at least once a year, even if your contract period is longer. This means that if changes need to be made that involve funding, you can put plans in place.
Always review your contract at least 6 months before it ends. If you need to make changes or switch providers, there may be a lengthy notice period.

internalName.en-US: Broadband connection - high recs - Review 1 x year - content

content.value: Continue to keep your broadband contract information updated on your contracts register.
Continue to review your broadband contract at least once a year, even if your contract period is longer. This means that if changes need to be made that involve funding, you can put plans in place.
Always review your contract at least 6 months before it ends. If you need to make changes or switch providers, there may be a lengthy notice period.

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - Question 2 - Answer - Every 1 to 2 years

text.en-US: Every 1 to 2 years

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - interstitial page  - Types of broadband - content

content.value: If you have a back-up broadband contract it should state what type of broadband you have. This could be:
copper, also described as fibre to the cabinet (FTTC) or asymmetric digital subscriber line (ADSL)
full fibre, also described as fibre to the premises (FTTP) or leased line
other, this could be 5G, satellite or another connection

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - interstitial page - Types of broadband - header

text.en-US: Types of broadband connections

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - Consider needs - header

text.en-US: Consider your school's back-up broadband needs

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - Decide when to install - header

text.en-US: Decide when to install back-up broadband

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - Decide when to install - content

content.value: Include funding for installing and maintaining a back-up broadband contract in your school improvement plan (SIP). This will help you to meet
broadband internet standards for schools and colleges

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - Consider needs - content

content.value: Your school’s back-up broadband only needs to run core school operations until your primary broadband connection is fixed.
For this reason, back-up broadband does not need the same bandwidth capacity as your primary connection and could be less expensive.
To work out the level of service you need from a back-up broadband connection, decide which systems are vital to allow your school to continue operating. This should include:
MIS
access control
safeguarding software
CCTV
telephones
Your back-up broadband service must have the same level of filtering and monitoring as your primary broadband service.
If your primary broadband failure continues, disaster recovery planning should take over.

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - What can help achieve - content

content.value: If your primary broadband connection fails, back-up broadband makes sure your school can:
continue to operate safely and effectively
use essential school services
avoid losing work or files
avoid having to close temporarily

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - What to consider - content

content.value: Installing back-up broadband can involve structural work to both your premises and nearby roads. You need to fund and plan this to avoid disruption during term time.

A back-up broadband connection should be part of your school’s disaster recovery planning. It should be good enough to keep essential core school operations running if your primary broadband connection fails. This includes your Management Information System (MIS) and security operations, such as filtering and monitoring.
If your school relies on cloud services, or you share your broadband with another school, you may need a back-up line with greater capacity.
You should only rely on your back-up broadband connection until your primary broadband connection is fixed.

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - Have a plan to install - title

text.en-US: Have a plan to install back-up broadband

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - Find what's available - header

text.en-US: Find out what back-up broadband connections are available

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - Find out if central contract - header

text.en-US: Find out if your school can join a centralised contract

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - How to prep for install - header

text.en-US: How to prepare for installation

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - Find what's available - content

content.value: Use the
Ofcom broadband checker
to find out what type of broadband is available in your area to use for back-up broadband. This could be 4G, 5G, fibre, satellite or another connection.
To reduce the risk of both back-up and primary broadband connections failing at the same time, consider:
using different providers
having different types of broadband, such as 4G, 5G, fibre, satellite or another type
connections that go to different off-site cabinets (if both back-up and primary broadband connections are full fibre broadband)

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - How to purchase - content

content.value: Put together a specification for back-up broadband that meets your school’s needs. The
Get help buying for schools service
can help.
When comparing quotes for back-up broadband and choosing a provider, ask your IT support to make sure:
the level of service meets, but does not exceed, your school’s needs
it includes the right level of filtering and monitoring services
your back-up broadband starts automatically if your primary connection fails
Try to choose a contract that is 3 years or fewer in length as technology changes quickly.
The
DfE telecoms and broadband matching frameworks service
can help you find preferred providers.

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - How to purchase - header

text.en-US: How to purchase back-up broadband

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - Find out if central contract - content

content.value: Ask your school business professional and, if relevant, your local authority or multi-academy trust if there’s a centralised or trust-wide contract your school can join. They might have a better deal you can benefit from.

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - How to prep for install - content

content.value: Ask your provider for advice on the most suitable location for your back-up broadband.
Ask your provider or IT support to set up core operational systems. This should include an automatic switchover if the primary broadband service fails.
On the day your back-up broadband is installed, make sure your IT support is available, preferably on site, to help with network setting changes. Ask your IT support to check that your settings meet
filtering and monitoring standards for schools and colleges

text.en-US: Review your back-up broadband contract at least once a year

text.en-US: Change or upgrade your back-up broadband

content.value: Installing back-up broadband can involve structural work to both your premises and nearby roads. You need to fund and plan this to avoid disruption during term time.

A back-up broadband connection should be part of your school’s disaster recovery planning. It should be good enough to keep essential core school operations running if your primary broadband connection fails. This includes your Management Information System (MIS) and security operations, such as filtering and monitoring.
If your school relies on cloud services, or you share your broadband with another school, you may need a back-up connection with greater capacity.
You should only rely on your back-up broadband connection until your primary broadband connection is fixed.

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - low recs - Review 1 x year - content

content.value: Add your new contract to your contracts register. This is a list of your school’s contracts, including type of contract, provider, and start, end and review dates. Make sure this document is available to everyone who makes decisions about technology in your school.

To make sure your back-up broadband continues to meet your school needs, review your contract at least once a year, even if your contract period is longer. This means that if changes need to be made that involve funding, you can put plans in place.
Always review your contract at least 6 months before it ends. If you need to make changes or switch providers there may be a lengthy notice period.

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - med recs - Why important - content

content.value: Copper broadband services, including asymmetric digital subscriber line (ADSL) and fibre to the cabinet (FTTC), will be switched off at the end of December 2025.
After this date, copper broadband, whether used for primary or back-up broadband, will no longer work.
The switch-off will happen in phases and may occur sooner in some areas.

telephones
Your back-up broadband service must have the same level of filtering and monitoring as your primary broadband service.
If your primary broadband failure continues, disaster recovery planning should take over.

text.en-US: Consider your school's network switching needs

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - high recs - Continue funding - header

text.en-US: Continue funding your back-up broadband

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - high recs - Continue funding - content

content.value: Make sure back-up broadband maintenance and renewal is part of your long-term procurement strategy.

internalName.en-US: Back-up broadband - med recs - Review 1 x year - content

content.value: Add your new contract to your contracts register. This is a list of your school’s contracts, including type of contract, provider, and start, end and review dates. Make sure this document is available to everyone who makes decisions about technology in your school.

To make sure your back-up broadband continues to meet your school needs, review your contract at least once a year, even if your contract period is longer. This means that if changes need to be made that involve funding, you can put plans in place.
Always review your contract at least 6 months before it ends. If you need to make changes or switch providers, there may be a lengthy notice period.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - What help achieve - content

content.value: A long-term plan to monitor and update your network switches will help your school to:
save money in the long term
maximise internet speed and reliability
use technology to support pupils better
save time caused by slow connection speeds
meet or exceed
network switching standards for schools and colleges

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Actions to take - content

content.value: If your school is already taking any of these actions, move to the next action.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Why important - content

content.value: Well-managed and maintained network switches will help to make sure your school has a reliable, secure network.
Network switches that are not fit for purpose can reduce productivity and put your school at risk of:
cyber attacks that affect your network
unauthorised access to the network by staff or pupils
data protection issues, including data loss
network failure

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - What to consider - content

content.value: Network switches affect the security and reliability of your school’s internet connection.
Switches are one part of your network. Internet speed and reliability can also be affected by:
broadband type
network cabling
wireless network

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - How and when improve - header

text.en-US: Work out when and how you can improve your network switches

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Consider school needs - content

content.value: Network switches are a vital part of your school’s IT network. Using the right type of switches will help to keep your school’s network safe, secure and working properly.
If your school sometimes has problems with slow, unreliable internet, check that your network switches meet
network switching standards for schools and colleges
Make sure that all your network switches are:
commercial or enterprise grade of a suitable quality (not domestic-use switches)
supplied with access controls and policy management
covered by an active warranty
running up-to-date software and firmware
centrally managed
located in a safe, secure place
reviewed annually
renewed when out of warranty or showing signs of potential failure
If your school still has some issues with slow or unreliable broadband, check your:
broadband connection
network cabling
wireless network

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Manage from central dash - content

content.value: You should have a central management dashboard to control and monitor your school’s network switches. This will make it easier to keep your school network secure and performing effectively.
If this does not exist, include funding to install switches with a central management tool in your SIP. The tool should:
be able to configure and manage core and edge switches
monitor switch performance
provide alerts if a switch fails
help you keep switches secure and updated
Whether or not you have central control, make sure there are dedicated people responsible for monitoring and maintaining your IT network.
This role should involve:
understanding the network
keeping software and firmware updated
monitoring and documenting patching schedules
making sure equipment remains in warranty
putting a refresh plan in action
making sure any additions or changes to the network meet
network switching standards for schools and colleges
monitoring and addressing faults as they happen
updating the network documentation on setup and operation as required, for example, if there are changes to the network
regularly reporting to and updating the senior leadership team

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - How and when improve - content

content.value: Install or replace any network switches that do not meet
network switching standards for schools and colleges
as part of a rolling annual investment programme.
Your school should also replace network switches:
when refurbishing all or part of a school building
when planning extensions or new school buildings
if a switch fails or is at risk of failure

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Protect users and data - content

content.value: Start by understanding what switches you have and how well they’re maintained, as this can affect security.
Ask your IT support if there is a documented plan of the network showing the systems each switch supports.
If this does not exist, ask your IT support to document the switch configuration and which systems it supports. This should include:
whether switches are configured to meet
network switching standards for schools and colleges
the process for keeping software and firmware updated
warranty expiry dates
network diagrams
details of network setups, including IP address ranges
Make this available to the team or person responsible for managing and maintaining the network. Make sure that any administrative accounts are secure and documented.
Plan to update or change any switches that do not meet
network switching standards for schools and colleges

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Protect users and data - header

text.en-US: Make sure you protect your users' data from unauthorised access

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Manage from central dash - header

text.en-US: Make sure your network switches are managed from a central dashboard or platform

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Work out whole life cost - header

text.en-US: Work out the whole life cost of your network switches

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Work out whole life cost - content

content.value: While commercial-grade network switches are more expensive, they are more secure and can save you money longer term. Domestic-grade switches are less secure, usually need replacing more often and can lack the support needed for a reliable network.
Make sure you know the whole life cost of your existing network by reviewing your annual network spend. This includes licences, warranties, replacements and support.

Record this information in your asset register. This is a list of your school’s physical assets, including type of asset, supplier, installation date, warranty and location. Make sure this document is available to everyone who makes decisions about technology in your school.

Knowing the whole life cost will help you make informed decisions when planning to buy new network switches. It also allows you to include fully costed plans to refresh and maintain your network switches in your school improvement plan (SIP).

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - high recs - Actions to take - content

content.value: Keep using the data you get from your centrally-managed wifi solution to check you’ll have enough bandwidth in future.
You should also plan for unpredictable use or increased demand by monitoring any bottlenecks you identify in your wifi network.

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - low rec - What to consider - content

content.value: You’ll need to replace your wifi infrastructure if it's:
negatively affecting teaching and learning
more than 5 years old
out of warranty
not enterprise grade
not centrally managed using a cloud-based or on-site solution

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Designed by professionals - content

content.value: Take this action if your school is planning to invest in:
a refurbishment
an extension
new buildings
its IT network

It’s important that your network switches are designed by professionals who will also provide you with a fully documented network plan. To give you peace of mind, suppliers should prove that they have manufacturer accreditation.
The supplier you use should:
be manufacturer-accredited
make sure that switches are configured properly
make it easy to monitor the network and identify faults
increase IT network security
prevent accidental or intentional loops that can cause network failure
avoid poor design, such as ‘daisy chaining’ where switches are attached to other switches
To improve your IT network:
Check that any network cabling that connects your switches to new technology or wifi access points can support any changes to your network.
Create a specification that meets your needs, the
Get help buying for schools service
can help.
Get quotes from 3 manufacturer-accredited suppliers.
Make sure your IT support is involved fully and on site when the work takes place.
Make sure your school is given documentation detailing the network.
Give relevant training to all colleagues who will use or monitor the network.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Designed by professionals - header

text.en-US: Make sure new networks are designed by manufacturer-accredited professionals

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - recommendations - high maturity

displayName.en-US: Check your wifi can continue to meet your future needs

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - high recs - Why important - content

content.value: You’ll need to keep providing enough bandwidth for pupils and staff who need to use your wifi.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - recommendations - low maturity

displayName.en-US: Have a plan to manage and improve network switches

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - low recs - Why rec important - content

content.value: While costly, it’s unlikely that you’ll be able to improve your wifi without replacing all or parts of your wifi.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Kept safe and secure - header

text.en-US: Keep network switches in a safe, secure location

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - low rec - Get review from specialist - heading

text.en-US: Get an initial review from a wifi specialist

internalName.en-US: Wireless network  - low recs - Get review from specialist - content

content.value: Many suppliers will do this initial review for free.
Ask the supplier for:
a heatmap
an overview of your whole wireless network, including your network switches, network cabling and broadband
When complete, ask the supplier:
to go through their findings with you
for detailed recommendations about how they’ll improve your wifi
for a full breakdown of their costs

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - low recs - What can achieve - content

content.value: You’ll be able to redesign your wifi with the help of a specialist so it meets your current and future needs.

internalName.en-US: Wireless - low recs - Initial review (not in use) - header

text.en-US: Get an initial review from a wifi specialist

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - low recs - Design new wifi - heading

text.en-US: Design your new wifi infrastructure

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - low recs - Get wifi survey - heading

text.en-US: Get a wifi site survey

internalName.en-US: Wireless - low recs - Initial review - content

content.value: Many suppliers will do this initial review for free.
Ask the supplier for:
a heatmap
an overview of your wifi network, including your network switches, data cabling and broadband
When complete, ask the supplier:
to go through their findings with you
for detailed recommendations about how they’ll improve your wifi network
for their costs

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - low recs - Design new wifi - content

content.value: Work with your supplier to get the coverage, speed, capacity and management tools that are right for your school’s future needs.
As a minimum, this should include:
reusing some of your existing infrastructure, where appropriate, to reduce costs
repositioning your existing wireless access points
getting a centrally-managed solution that allows you to manage your wireless access points
ensuring your centrally-managed solution and wireless access points always have the latest security and system updates
whether you’d benefit from Wi-Fi 6, the latest standard of wifi
getting guest wifi, if you need it, and setting it up securely
VLANs to segregate different traffic on your network, for example, guests and pupils, and for different purposes such as CCTV and video
external wireless access points if you need high-quality wifi outdoors

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - low recs - Get wifi survey - content

content.value: Once you’ve selected a supplier, ask them for a wifi site survey. This is a full analysis of your wifi network.
Your supplier will use it to:
diagnose what's causing problems with your signal and coverage
recommend ways you can improve your signal and coverage
recommend redesigning your wifi network if it needs replacing

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - low recs - Install new wifi - heading

text.en-US: Installing your new wifi network

internalName.en-US: Wireless network -  low recs - Involve IT - inset text

text.en-US: Make sure you involve your IT support throughout this process.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Kept safe and secure - content

content.value: For safety and security, network switches (and servers) should be in a well-ventilated cabinet in a secure, dedicated space or room. Cables and wires should be as short as possible and neatly arranged in the cabinet.
If your school building does not have space for a dedicated server room, prioritise investment for a lockable, secure cabinet designed for servers and switches.
Only authorised people should have access to rooms and cabinets containing network switches to prevent:
accidental or malicious damage
data damage and theft

Network switches are high-voltage and ampere systems. There should be no water pipes in, above or near the room or cabinet. Do not store other items or equipment in the same room or cabinet as your network switches. This helps to prevent:
unauthorised access
dust causing the network switches to overheat and fail
water or liquid causing a short circuit and system failure
other flammable materials causing a fire hazard

Do not locate servers and switches in classrooms or offices, even in locked cabinets, as it increases potential cyber security risks. Servers are also noisy and hard to access in busy classrooms and offices.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Keep software updated - header

text.en-US: Keep network switching software updated

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - low recs - Install new wifi - content

content.value: Make sure your supplier provides full documentation and training on any new systems they’ve installed or changes they’ve made to your network.
Also check whether your supplier:
charges for on-going support
can offer a 5-year warranty

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Keep software updated - content

content.value: Software and firmware updates make sure that your IT network remains as secure as possible.
Make sure there is a process to update software and firmware as soon as a new version becomes available.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Always under warranty - header

text.en-US: Make sure network switches are always under warranty

internalName.en-US: Wireless - low recs - Using your new network - header

text.en-US: Using your new network

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Always under warranty - content

content.value: If a switch fails, all or part of your network will be unavailable. This can affect teaching, learning and daily operations.
Having network switches under warranty will help to make sure that if a switch fails, it can be replaced as quickly as possible.
This should be part of your school’s disaster recovery plan.
To make improvements:
Identify which switches are out of warranty.
Prioritise funding to replace network switches that are out of warranty in your SIP.
Start a rolling replacement plan to make sure that network switches are always covered by an active warranty.
Have a dedicated person or team responsible for monitoring and maintaining your network switches.
Review your IT network at least once a year.
Add network switches to your disaster recovery plan.

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - What can achieve - content

content.value: You’ll be able to:
get fast and fully-functioning wifi where you need it
improve security and safeguarding
manage your wifi and capacity more easily

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Connect to back up power - content

content.value: A short-term back-up power source, also known as an uninterruptible power supply (UPS), makes sure your school can operate if the primary power supply varies or fails. It also reduces the risk of losing data.

Work with your IT support to find out which switches are critical to your school’s daily operations. This should include switches that support your phones, servers, internet, filtering and monitoring, CCTV and Management Information System (MIS).
These critical switches should be supported by a UPS.

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - What to consider - content

content.value: You may need to improve other things first before you can improve your wifi, such as your cabling, switches and broadband.
If you haven’t already, try to complete all the connectivity topics in
your technology self-assessment

internalName.en-US: Network switches - low recs - Connect to back up power - header

text.en-US: Connect critical switches to at least one back-up power supply

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Check how you can improve your wifi - title

text.en-US: Check how you can improve your wifi

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Why rec important - content

content.value: Working systematically will help you:
get the level of wifi that’s right for your school’s circumstances
plan things in the right order
know what you can do yourself and what you’ll need a specialist supplier for
work out what you can do now and what you can plan to do later

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Check signal and coverage - heading

text.en-US: Check where your signal and coverage are weak

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Consider upgrading Wi-Fi 6 - heading

text.en-US: Consider upgrading to Wi-Fi 6

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Consider upgrading Wi-Fi 6 - content

content.value: When your wifi system is more than 5 years old or out of warranty, you’ll need to replace it.
Before you do this, ask your IT support whether you'd benefit from replacing it with Wi-Fi 6 (802.11ax), the latest standard of wifi.

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Check access points - content

content.value: Install at least one access point in each room or classroom if you haven't already.
You may need several for larger spaces such as halls or where you use lots of wireless devices such as libraries.
You may only need to do this in the areas where you use wireless devices.
If you already have enough access points, ask your estates team whether you can reposition your existing access points.
Generally, access points are most effective when they are placed in the centre of the room at a height of about 2.4 metres.
Then check whether the signal and coverage have improved. If not, you may need to get advice from a wifi specialist.
In this case, ask whoever makes procurement decisions in your school about getting a wifi specialist for an initial review or a full wifi site survey.

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Check access points - heading

text.en-US: Check your access points

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Check signal and coverage - content

content.value: Try to find out where in your school you’re struggling to get signal and coverage.
If you’re unsure how to check for wifi signal and coverage, follow these steps:
L
oad a video on a mobile device.
C
onnect to wifi and switch off mobile data.
W
alk through all your school buildings.
Where the video stops or the streaming quality is poor, this probably means that you're not getting good enough signal or coverage in that area.
You should target these areas first by following the remaining actions in this recommendation.
If you identify a large number of areas where signal or coverage are weak, you may need to get advice from a specialist supplier about improving your wifi.

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Plan for WiFi6 - heading

text.en-US: Plan for Wi-Fi 6

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Plan for WiFi6 - content

content.value: Because Wi-Fi 6 can be more expensive than existing wifi systems, you’ll need to check whether it’s right for your school and plan for it.
This planning could include assessing your current needs first. For example, if you’re happy with your current wifi speed, coverage and capacity, you may not need Wi-Fi 6.
Also consider your future needs. If you anticipate an increase in users and devices, Wi-Fi 6 may give you more capacity without affecting speed or coverage.
You'll need to work with whoever is responsible for financial decisions in your school so you can budget for the upgrade.
Even if you don’t need to get Wi-Fi 6 right now, you’ll need to upgrade your wifi at some point in the future and have the budget available to do this.

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Manage bandwidth - content

content.value: Ask your IT support whether you’ll need to:
limit the number of devices that can connect your wifi at certain times
limit bandwidth per device to prevent a single user from overwhelming the network
set up quality of service settings to prioritise things that are important and use a lot of data, such as CCTV or video

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Keep wifi updated - heading

text.en-US: Keep your centrally-managed wifi solution updated

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Segment traffic - heading

text.en-US: Segment traffic on your network

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Keep wifi updated - content

content.value: Ask your IT support to check for system updates and ensure these are installed as soon as they’re available.
This is essential for network security as well as helping to improve performance.
If you have a cloud-based system to manage your wifi, you should receive these updates automatically.

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Segment traffic - content

content.value: Ask your IT support whether you’ll need to segregate your traffic into separate networks (called VLANs) for pupils, teachers, administrative staff and guests.
This can improve performance as well as security.
For example, you’ll need to prevent unauthorised staff from accessing certain files and information as part of safeguarding the personal data of your pupils and staff.

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Manage bandwidth - heading

text.en-US: Manage your bandwidth

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - What to consider - content

content.value: Network switches affect the security and reliability of your school’s internet connection.
Switches are one part of your network. Internet speed and reliability can also be affected by:
broadband type
network cabling
wireless network

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Actions to take - content

content.value: If your school is already taking any of these actions, move to the next action.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - What help achieve - content

content.value: A long-term plan to monitor and update your network switches will help your school to:
save money in the long term
maximise internet speed and reliability
use technology to support pupils better
save time caused by slow connection speeds
meet or exceed
network switching standards for schools and colleges

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Turn off wifi - content

content.value: Ask your IT support whether you can turn off your wifi when you’re not using it, for example, during the holidays or weekends.
Some systems will also allow you to turn off different networks but leave others on.
For example, in the evenings, you could turn off your guest wifi but leave your main wifi on for your staff.

internalName.en-US: Wireless network - mid recs - Turn off wifi - heading

text.en-US: Turn off your wifi when you’re not using it

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Improve how manage and control - title

text.en-US: Improve how you control and manage network switches

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Why rec important - content

content.value: Well-managed and maintained network switches will help to make sure your school has a reliable, secure network.
Network switches that are not fit for purpose can reduce productivity and put your school at risk of:
cyber attacks that affect your network
unauthorised access to the network by staff or pupils
data protection issues, including data loss
network failure

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - How and when improve - header

text.en-US: Work out when and how you can improve your network switches

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Consider school needs - content

content.value: Network switches are a vital part of your school’s IT network. Using the right type of switches will help to keep your school’s network safe, secure and working properly.
If your school sometimes has problems with slow, unreliable internet, check that your network switches meet
network switching standards for schools and colleges
Make sure that all your network switches are:
commercial or enterprise grade of a suitable quality (not domestic-use switches)
supplied with network access controls and policy management
covered by an active warranty
running up-to-date software and firmware
centrally managed
located in a safe, secure place
reviewed annually
renewed when out of warranty or showing signs of potential failure
If your school still has some issues with slow or unreliable broadband, check:
broadband connection
network cabling
wireless network

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Consider school needs  - header

text.en-US: Consider your school's network switching needs

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Manage from central dash - header

text.en-US: Make sure your network switches are managed from a central dashboard or platform

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Work out whole life cost - content

content.value: While commercial-grade network switches are more expensive, they are more secure and can save you money longer term. Domestic-grade switches are less secure, usually need replacing more often and can lack the support needed for a reliable network.
Make sure you know the whole life cost of your existing network by reviewing your annual network spend. This includes licences, warranties, replacements and support.

Record this information in your asset register. This is a list of your school’s physical assets, including type of asset, supplier, installation date, warranty and location. Make sure this document is available to everyone who makes decisions about technology in your school.

Knowing the whole life cost will help you make informed decisions when planning to buy new network switches. It also allows you to include fully costed plans to refresh and maintain your network switches in your school improvement plan (SIP).

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - How and when improve - content

content.value: Install or replace any network switches that do not meet
network switching standards for schools and colleges
as part of a rolling annual investment programme.
Your school should also replace network switches:
when refurbishing all or part of a school building
when planning extensions or new school buildings
if a switch fails or is at risk of failure

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Work out whole life cost - header

text.en-US: Work out the whole life cost of your network switches

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Designed by professionals - header

text.en-US: Make sure new networks are designed by manufacturer-accredited professionals

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Kept safe and secure - content

content.value: For safety and security, network switches (and servers) should be in a well-ventilated cabinet in a secure, dedicated space or room. Cables and wires should be as short as possible and neatly arranged in the cabinet.
If your school building does not have space for a dedicated server room, prioritise investment for a lockable, secure cabinet designed for servers and switches.
Only authorised people should have access to rooms and cabinets containing network switches to prevent:
accidental or malicious damage
data damage and theft

Network switches are high-voltage and ampere systems. There should be no water pipes in, above or near the room or cabinet. Do not store other items or equipment in the same room or cabinet as your network switches. This helps to prevent:
unauthorised access
dust causing the network switches to overheat and fail
water or liquid causing a short circuit and system failure
other flammable materials causing a fire hazard

Do not locate servers and switches in classrooms or offices, even in locked cabinets, as it increases potential cyber security risks. Servers are also noisy and hard to access in busy classrooms and offices.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Manage from central dash - content

content.value: You should have a central management dashboard to control and monitor your school’s network switches. This will make it easier to keep your school network secure and performing effectively.
If this does not exist, include funding to install switches with a central management tool in your SIP. The tool should:
be able to configure and manage core and edge switches
monitor switch performance
provide alerts if a switch fails
help you keep switches secure and updated
Whether or not you have central control, make sure there are dedicated people responsible for monitoring and maintaining your IT network.
This role should involve:
understanding the network
keeping software and firmware updated
monitoring and documenting patching schedules
making sure equipment remains in warranty
putting a refresh plan in action
making sure any additions or changes to the network meet
network switching standards for schools and colleges
monitoring and addressing faults as they happen
updating the network documentation on setup and operation as required, for example, if there are changes to the network
regularly reporting to and updating the senior leadership team

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Designed by professionals - content

content.value: Take this action if your school is planning to invest in:
a refurbishment
an extension
new buildings
its IT network

It’s important that your network switches are designed by professionals who will also provide you with a fully documented network plan. To give you peace of mind, suppliers should prove that they have manufacturer accreditation.
The supplier you use should:
be manufacturer-accredited
make sure that switches are configured properly
make it easy to monitor the network and identify faults
increase IT network security
prevent accidental or intentional loops that can cause network failure
avoid poor design, such as ‘daisy chaining’ where switches are attached to other switches
To improve your IT network:
Check that any network cabling that connects your switches to new technology or wifi access points can support any changes to your network.
Create a specification that meets your needs, the
Get help buying for schools service
can help.
Get quotes from 3 manufacturer-accredited suppliers.
Make sure your IT support is involved fully and on site when the work takes place.
Make sure your school is given documentation detailing the network.
Give relevant training to all colleagues who will use or monitor the network.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Protect users and data - header

text.en-US: Make sure you protect your users' data from unauthorised access

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Kept safe and secure - header

text.en-US: Keep network switches in a safe, secure location

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Protect users and data - content

content.value: Start by understanding what switches you have and how well they’re maintained, as this can affect security.
Ask your IT support if there is a documented plan of the network showing the systems each switch supports.
If this does not exist, ask your IT support to document the switch configuration and which systems it supports. This should include:
whether switches are configured to meet
network switching standards for schools and colleges
the process for keeping software and firmware updated
warranty expiry dates
network diagrams
details of network setups, including IP address ranges
Make this available to the team or person responsible for managing and maintaining the network. Make sure that any administrative accounts are secure and documented.
Plan to update or change any switches that do not meet
network switching standards for schools and colleges

internalName.en-US: Network switches - high recs - Continue monitoring - title

text.en-US: Continue monitoring and maintaining your network switches

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Always under warranty - header

text.en-US: Make sure network switches are always under warranty

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Keep software updated - header

text.en-US: Keep network switching software updated

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Connect to back up power - header

text.en-US: Connect critical switches to at least one back-up power supply

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Connect to back up power - content

content.value: A short-term back-up power source, also known as an uninterruptible power supply (UPS), makes sure your school can operate if the primary power supply varies or fails. It also reduces the risk of losing data.
Work with your IT support to find out

which switches are critical to your school’s daily operations. This should include switches that support your phones, servers, internet, filtering and monitoring, CCTV and Management Information System (MIS).
These critical switches should be supported by a UPS.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Always under warranty - content

content.value: If a switch fails, all or part of your network will be unavailable. This can affect teaching, learning and daily operations.
Having network switches under warranty will help to make sure that if a switch fails, it can be replaced as quickly as possible.
This should be part of your school’s disaster recovery plan.
To make improvements:
Identify which switches are out of warranty.
Prioritise funding to replace network switches that are out of warranty in your SIP.
Start a rolling replacement plan to make sure that network switches always covered by an active warranty.
Have a dedicated person or team responsible for monitoring and maintaining your network switches.
Review your IT network at least once a year.
Add network switches to your disaster recovery plan.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - med recs - Keep software updated - content

content.value: Software and firmware updates make sure that your IT network remains as secure as possible.
Make sure there is a process to update software and firmware as soon as a new version becomes available.

internalName.en-US: Network switches - high recs - Keep monitoring - content

content.value: As part of a good digital strategy, you should continue to review your network switches at least once a year to make sure:
switches are still covered by an active warranty
software is up to date
switches are kept in an appropriate environment, for example, a locked, dedicated room or cabinet with good ventilation

internalName.en-US: Network switches - high recs - Consider switches when expanding - header

text.en-US: Consider switches when expanding your network

internalName.en-US: Network switches - high recs - Actions to take - content

content.value: From your answers your school is already meeting, and possibly exceeding, the
network switching standards for schools and colleges

text.en-US: What personal data we collect and process

internalName.en-US: Privacy policy - When we’ll share your personal information - header

text.en-US: When we’ll share your personal information

internalName.en-US: Privacy policy - Why we’re allowed to use your personal data - header

text.en-US: Why we’re allowed to use your personal data

internalName.en-US: Network switches - high recs - Consider switches when expanding - content

content.value: If you expand your network or plan an extension or new build, you may need to review your network switches.
Make sure you consider your school’s new technology needs, including network switches, at the planning stage.
Any network switches you add should meet the
network switching standards for schools and colleges

internalName.en-US: Privacy policy - Why we’re allowed to use your personal data - content

content.value: This service meets the requirements of a ‘public task’ under Article 6 (1)(e) of the GDPR and relies on the following legislation:
section 8 of the Data Protection Act 2018 – exercising official authority as part of public body tasks and Department for Education functions
section 10 of the Education Act 1996 – general duty on the Secretary of State for Education to promote the education of people in England

internalName.en-US: Vision and roles - low recs - Make sure someone on SLT resp for IT- content

content.value: Your SLT should include someone who is responsible for your technology strategy. This person should have management skills, rather than lots of technical knowledge.
It should not be the same person who looks after your IT network day-to-day. This helps to make sure that decisions about technology meet your educational needs.
Clearly define and document responsibilities for this role. These should include:
creating a technology strategy that meets your school’s needs
making sure your technology strategy is part of your school improvement plan (SIP)
developing a 3-year budget for technology
monitoring and reporting on progress and compliance at SLT meetings
reviewing and updating your technology strategy at least once a year

internalName.en-US: Privacy policy - What personal data we collect and process - content

content.value: When you use DfE sign-in, we collect and use this personal information.
Data collected
Why we collect this data

For example, to contact you about occasional service updates

Data collected
Why we collect this data

For example, to contact you about occasional service updates

Other information, such as your age, gender and ethnicity
For statistical analysis
If you participate in any surveys or research as part of this service, we’ll also link this data with the personal information we’ve already collected from you.
This is so we can further understand your users’ needs and improve the service we offer you.

internalName.en-US: Accessibility - What to do if you cannot access parts of this service - content

content.value: Email us if you:
need information from this service in a different format, such as an accessible PDF or in large print
find any accessibility errors
want to bring any accessibility issues to our attention
We’ll aim to get back to you within 5 working days.
Email technology.planning@education.gov.uk

internalName.en-US: Accessibility - Introduction - text

content.value: This statement was prepared on 26 September 2023.
Plan technology for your school is a service run by the Department for Education (DfE).
We want as many people as possible to be able to use our service. For example, that means you should be able to:
change colours, contrast levels and fonts
zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
navigate most of the service using just a keyboard
navigate most of the service using speech recognition software
listen to most of the service using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
AbilityNet
has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.

internalName.en-US: DSI error page - no organisation or approval combined - intro - Content

content.value: To use the Plan technology for your school service you need to be associated with an organisation, which could be your school or another organisation. A recognised approver from your organisation must then give you permission to use our service:
Log into your
DfE Sign-in account
and make sure you have selected your organisation.
Contact a recognised approver from the list in the organisation section of your DfE Sign-in account, to ask for permission.

internalName.en-US: DSI error page - no organisation or approval combined - more help - content

content.value: If you are still unable to log in using DfE Sign-in, ask the person responsible for setting up your school email accounts to check that:
your school is registered to use DfE Sign-in
your email is linked to your school
Get more
help with DfE Sign-in

internalName.en-US: Digital technology registers - interstitial page
Digital technology registers - interstitial page - title

text.en-US: Preparing for the digital technology registers topic

internalName.en-US: Leadership and governance - Digital technology registers - Section
Digital technology registers - interstitial page - Preparing for the digital technology registers topic - content

content.value: There are 3 digital technology registers that help schools monitor and plan for digital technology. They may be separate documents or part of your school’s general registers:
digital technology asset register
- hardware and equipment log
digital technology contracts register
- contracts, licences, subscriptions, apps and digital certificates log
information asset register (IAR) -
digital data sources log, also known as a data asset register
This topic includes a maximum of 10 multiple choice questions about digital technology registers. Depending on your responses, you might not need to answer all the questions.

internalName.en-US: Digital technology registers - interstitial page - Involve the right people and teams - header

text.en-US: Involve the right people and teams

internalName.en-US: Digital technology registers - interstitial page - Involve the right people and teams - content

content.value: It’s likely that different people and teams will have the information needed to answer the questions. You may need input from:
the senior leadership team member responsible for digital technology
your school’s business manager or finance team
your data protection officer
the person or team who maintains your IT network
anyone else who looks after your digital technology registers

internalName.en-US: Digital technology registers - interstitial page - How your school can benefit - header

text.en-US: How your school can benefit

internalName.en-US: Digital technology registers - interstitial page - How your school can benefit - content

content.value:
We’ll use your answers to give you a better understanding of what you’re doing well, along with recommendations and actions to help you do some things even better. 

Your school should not need extra funding for these recommendations. Some actions may even help you to save money.

internalName.en-US: Digital technology registers - interstitial page - What you'll need to know - header

text.en-US: What you'll need to know

internalName.en-US: Digital technology registers - interstitial page - What you'll need to know - content

content.value: Before starting this topic, try to find out if your school has digital technology registers. If so, ask:
Are they up to date?
Who, if anyone, updates and monitors your digital technology registers?

Some schools prefer to have a meeting with all relevant people to answer the questions together. Alternatively, an individual team member can complete the topic. 

There is no time limit. You can leave and return to the service at any time as your answers automatically save as you go along.
